text:
Professor Dave here, let’s talk about points,
lines, and planes.

As we just discussed, geometry was developed
in ancient Greece, and when we learn the geometry

of this time, we refer to it as Euclidian
geometry, in reference to the mathematician
Euclid, to whom it is attributed.

His work, which built upon the work of earlier
mathematicians like Pythagoras, describes

a set of axioms and postulates from which
a variety of theorems can be derived.

Let’s learn about the physical constructs
that these axioms describe so that we can
learn about all the math we can do with them.
First we look at a point.
This is nothing more than a location in space.

It is zero-dimensional, meaning that it has
no dimensions of any kind.

We represent points with little dots and some
capital letter, making sure to realize that

the dot we draw is infinitely larger than
the point it is meant to represent.

From here, we can construct a one-dimensional
object by stringing an infinite number of
points along a particular dimension.
This object is called a line.

Points and lines are familiar to us from algebra,
but now let’s examine a two-dimensional
object.

This can be achieved by stringing an infinite
number of lines along a dimension perpendicular
to the line.
This is called a plane.

And then if we string an infinite number of
planes in either direction, we get three-dimensional
space.
Point, line, plane, space.
Zero, one, two, and three dimensions.

Another linearity we can identify is that
a point is just a point, but any two points

can define a line, since there is only one
line that contains both of these points.

Extrapolating further, any three points that
aren’t all colinear can define a plane,

since there is only one plane that contains
all three of these points.

We should mention that these figures are idealized
concepts.

We can never create a plane that is infinitely
thin so as to legitimately consist of only
two spatial dimensions.

Even a piece of paper has some thickness,
even if it’s hard to see with the human
eye.

But we can create mental idealizations of
these objects and discuss them concretely,

and the conclusions we draw from them will
have application in the physical world, where

we can approximate certain systems as being
perfectly Euclidian.

Just to list a bit more terminology, while
a line extends infinitely along its one dimension

in both directions, if we chop one end off,
giving it a definite starting point, we call
this a ray.

If we chop off both ends, leaving some chunk
left over in the middle, this is called a
line segment.

Line segments have two endpoints, rays have
one endpoint, and lines have none.

We can use lines, rays, and line segments
to generate all kinds of figures.

We can make shapes with differing numbers
of sides, and we can also create all kinds
of angles between these lines.

There is plenty to discuss regarding the types
of angles that are possible, their magnitudes,

and their relationships, so let’s move on
and talk about angles.
